text: now still no deal between Egypt and
Ethiopia over an enormous new dam the
Ethiopia is built on the Blue Nile there
had been another round of talks but
still no progress the three countries
affected are Ethiopia Egypt and Sudan
they're all now going to brief the
African Union on where they've got to
which is not - a deal
the official name for this project is
the grand Ethiopian Renaissance dam it
has the potential to control much of the
water that Egypt uses and when it's at
full tilt it'll be the largest
hydroelectric plant in Africa Ethiopia
is hope is that this will provide
electricity to over 65 million of its
people who are currently without regular
electricity the construction is just
about done it begun back in 2011 is very
close to complete now the crucial
question is when to fill up the dams
reservoir and then how much water
Ethiopia will guarantee it will release
and these matters are not agreed
Ethiopia said many times it will start
filling up the reservoir this month to
coincide with the rainy season that's a
process that is expected to take up to
seven years but there are suggestions
that ethiop is already begun filling the
dam this is a satellite image from the
26th of June you can see the Blue Nile
flowing right-to-left through the dam
this is another satellite image taken on
the 12th of July which shows water
levels a prison on the right side of the
dam which is where the reservoir will be
now Ethiopia is denied filling it up and
says the water levels are just due to
heavy rains that's something which has
happened in the past so it's not
possible to be certain whether this is
deliberate or not but Ethiopia is
embassy in the UK has certainly made its
position clear on its Twitter account
using the hashtag it's our dam on its
profile but name and the banner picture
- well Cameron Hudson from the director
of African affairs in the US National
Security Council under president george
w bush is now based at the atlantic
council and joins us live thank you very
much indeed for your time and just help
people coming to this story for the
first time understand what are the main
obstacles to a deal here well
principally I think the the obstacles
are simply that what's going to happen
in times of drought I think that when
when the rain falls are plentiful
there's not a lot of concern about how
quickly the dam will be filled and how
much water will be released through the
dam downriver to Sudan and to to Egypt I
think the big questions surround what
happens in those drought years when
Ethiopia is being asked to release more
water which means produce less
electricity or when Ethiopia or rather
Egypt is facing drought conditions and
needs more water but Ethiopia and Sudan
have become more reliant upon
electricity because they have
industrialized those regions which can't
afford to give up that electricity and
so it's really a question of what
happens in the in the drought years
that's the biggest I think obstacle to
overcome right now and you help to
advise the the Bush administration on
Africa security matters would you
qualify this story this standoff as a
security issue now well certainly both
Ethiopia and Egypt have defined this as
being in their national security
interest so from that perspective both
sides have have in recent days issued
some kind of saber-rattling statements
suggesting that this was core that there
was in fact an existential threat to
both sides whether on the Ethiopia side
if they could turn on the dam on the
Egyptian side whether they would be
denied water so that kind of language in
in the diplomatic space suggests that
that there are national security threats
Egypt
just last month took this issue to the
UN Security Council saying that there
was a potential threat to peace and
stability and security which is why it
asks the UN to take this up so so I
think all sides are treating this as a
potential threat to peace and security
in the region
Cameron I've already got 30 seconds but
do you wish Donald Trump would intervene
more directly to try and resolve this
well the Trump administration intervened
at the beginning of the year I believe
that the Ethiopians thought that they
came in too much on the side of Egypt
which is why the negotiations have
reverted back to both the UN and to the
African Union so I think also
now are seeking a more regional
mediation not one driven from Washington
